name: Xiang Li

researchThemes.title: Geometry-based trajectory analysis
researchThemes.oneLiner: Predict correctness from hidden-state trajectories—no ground-truth labels.
researchThemes.question: What can we learn from hidden-state trajectories?
researchThemes.details_md: I treat hidden-state trajectories as **high-dimensional geometry** and design compact metrics to detect anomaly signatures (e.g., hallucination vs. correct reasoning).

researchThemes.title: Unsupervised cluster-as-lens
researchThemes.oneLiner: Track concept formation via split/merge transitions across layers.
researchThemes.question: How to study more about model internals?
researchThemes.details_md: Layer-wise clustering reveals **emergence / splitting / merging** of representation groups—useful for safety checks, hallucination detection, and editing.

featuredWork.title: How to explore trajectories within model internals

about_md: Hi — I'm Xiang Li. I build tools to see inside AI — so we can trust **what it thinks**, not just what it says. I'm currently a research intern at Stony Brook University, fortunate to be advised by [Prof. Jiawei Zhou](https://joezhouai.com/). I got my M.S. from University of Chicago, and my B.S. from Sichuan University, where I was advised by [Prof. Ta-Ping Lu](https://scupi.scu.edu.cn/en/faculty-staff-en/faculty-en/robert-lu).
